title: Rupsa and the Game | CodeChef
statement:
Princess Rupsa saw one of her friends playing a special game. The game goes as follows:
 
 N+1  numbers occur sequentially (one at a time) from  A 0  to  A N . 
 You must write the numbers on a sheet of paper, such that  A 0  is written first. The other numbers are written according to an inductive rule — after  A i-1  numbers have been written in a row, then  A i  can be written at either end of the row. That is, you first write  A 0 , and then  A 1  can be written on its left or right to make  A 0 A 1  or  A 1 A 0 , and so on. 
 A i  must be written before writing  A j , for every  i < j . 
 For a move in which you write a number  A i  (i>0) , your points increase by the product of  A i  and its neighbour. (Note that for any move it will have only one neighbour as you write the number at an end). 
 Total score of a game is the score you attain after placing all the  N + 1  numbers. Princess Rupsa wants to find out the sum of scores obtained by all possible different gameplays. Two gameplays are different, if after writing down all  N + 1  numbers, when we read from left to right, there exists some position  i , at which the gameplays have  a j  and  a k  written at the  i th  position such that  j ≠ k . But since she has recently found her true love, a frog Prince, and is in a hurry to meet him, you must help her solve the problem as fast as possible. Since the answer can be very large, print the answer modulo  10 9  + 7 .    Fetching successful submissions Program should read from  standard input  and write to  standard output .  After you submit a solution you can see your results by clicking on the  [My Submissions]  tab on the problem page.
